title: Paul and Barnabas in Lycaonia
shortSummary: Acts 14 recounts Paul and Barnabas’s missionary journey through Iconium, Lystra, and Derbe, where they face both acceptance and fierce opposition. Miracles performed by Paul lead to both worship by the people and violent persecution, yet the apostles continue to strengthen new believers and appoint leaders in the churches they establish.
timeline: c. AD 47-48 - Paul's First Missionary Journey

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: An apostle and primary missionary who boldly preaches the gospel, performs miracles, and endures persecution.

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: Paul’s companion and fellow apostle who supports and ministers alongside Paul throughout the journey.

keyCharacters.name: Unbelieving Jews
keyCharacters.description: Opponents who stir up Gentiles against the apostles, leading to conflict and violence.

keyCharacters.name: Certain Jews from Antioch and Iconium
keyCharacters.description: They incite the crowd to stone Paul, believing him to be dead.

definitions.definition: A Jewish place of worship and teaching where Paul and Barnabas initially preach.
A region in Asia Minor where Lystra and Derbe are located, known for its pagan worship.
Spiritual leaders appointed in the early churches to shepherd and guide the believers.
Worthless idols or false gods, contrasted with the living God in Paul’s preaching.

outline.heading: Preaching and Opposition in Iconium
outline.description: Paul and Barnabas preach boldly in the synagogue, resulting in many conversions but also division and opposition from unbelieving Jews who incite hostility.

outline.heading: Miracle and Misunderstanding in Lystra
outline.description: Paul heals a crippled man, leading the crowd to mistake them for gods; the apostles quickly correct this idolatry by pointing to the living Creator God.

outline.heading: Persecution and Perseverance
outline.description: Paul is stoned and left for dead but miraculously recovers, demonstrating the cost of gospel ministry and God’s sustaining power.

outline.heading: Strengthening the Churches
outline.description: Paul and Barnabas revisit the new believers, encouraging them to remain faithful and appointing elders to provide ongoing leadership.

outline.heading: Journey’s End and Report to Antioch
outline.description: The missionaries continue their journey through Pisidia and Pamphylia before returning to Antioch, where they report on God’s work among the Gentiles.

application: Boldly proclaim the gospel even in the face of opposition, trusting God to confirm His word with signs and wonders.
Correct misunderstandings about God quickly and clearly, pointing others to the true living Creator rather than idols or false beliefs.
Persevere through trials and persecution, knowing that suffering is part of the Christian journey toward the kingdom of God.
Support and strengthen fellow believers by encouraging faithfulness and appointing godly leaders to shepherd the church.

keyVerses.text: Long time therefore abode they speaking boldly in the Lord, which gave testimony unto the word of his grace, and granted signs and wonders to be done by their hands.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the boldness of the apostles and God’s confirmation of their message through miraculous signs.

keyVerses.text: And saying, Sirs, why do ye these things? We also are men of like passions with you, and preach unto you that ye should turn from these vanities unto the living God, which made heaven, and earth, and the sea, and all things that are therein:
keyVerses.significance: Paul and Barnabas reject idolatry and call people to repentance toward the one true Creator God.

keyVerses.text: Confirming the souls of the disciples, and exhorting them to continue in the faith, and that we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches the necessity of perseverance through trials as part of the Christian walk.

keyVerses.text: And when they were come, and had gathered the church together, they rehearsed all that God had done with them, and how he had opened the door of faith unto the Gentiles.
keyVerses.significance: The report to the Antioch church emphasizes God’s sovereign work in expanding the gospel to the Gentiles.
